props.synopsis: The former deputy leader of South Australia's Child Protection Department, believed to be the first Aboriginal person appointed to the role, has accused his former workplace of racism, claiming the agency told him it "owned" him for the duration of his contract.

title.children: Former SA Child Protection Department deputy says agency told him it 'owned' him

image.altText: A police car parked outside a brick unit in Mount Gambier with police tape on the fence

props.synopsis: The 53-year-old man is expected to be charged with murder later today.

title.children: Man arrested following woman's 'unexplained death' in Mount Gambier

image.altText: Birds eye view of coal mine

props.synopsis: Hundreds of workers at a coal mine owned by British billionaire Sanjeev Gupta have been stood down after suppliers refused to deliver critical materials over unpaid debts.

title.children: 'Anxious' workers at GFG Alliance mine stood down amid unpaid debts

image.altText: A paper sign taped to a black fence telling people about a childcare centre being shut down

props.synopsis: Issues with cleanliness, fencing and a smell "that needs to be investigated" has led the state's education standards regulator to temporarily close a childcare centre in Adelaide's north.

title.children: Childcare centre temporarily closed to fix fence, flooring and smell

image.altText: An older man on a gurney is attended to on an airstrip.

props.synopsis: Ian Jackson was 80 kilometres away from the nearest medical clinic when he was bitten by one of the world's deadliest snakes. He was all alone — except for the voice in his head that told him to stay calm.

title.children: 'A bit of bad luck': 73yo back at work a day after eastern brown bite

image.altText: A small boat with three people aboard speeds across the ocean.

props.synopsis: The routine boarding of a fishing vessel in SA's Spencer Gulf went wrong last week and a seaman who witnessed the incident says lives are being put at risk needlessly.

title.children: Call to end at-sea boarding after fisheries boat rolls in shark territory

props.synopsis: Two different agricultural enterprises have come together to tackle Australia's food waste challenge in an unexpected way — using the humble fly.

title.children: Fly larvae happy to munch on winery waste to make fertiliser

image.altText: A court sketch of Keith Russell Yandle.

props.synopsis: A jury hearing evidence in a murder trial have watched CCTV of the incident and handled a semi-automatic rifle used in the alleged shooting murder of Steven Murphy in February 2023.

title.children: Jury examines semi-auto rifle and shown CCTV of alleged shooting murder

image.altText: Mavro, a black dog who is blind, has his head turned to the side and his mouth open.

props.synopsis: When Amy van Dyk noticed her pooch Mavro was 'running into things', she thought he was simply a clumsy puppy. She soon discovered he had a vision impairment — but that hasn't stopped Mavro from hiking, swimming and dog sledding.

title.children: From hiking to sledding, blind dog Mavro 'just keeps going'

image.altText: A lifejacket on a wooden jetty.

props.synopsis: A run of fatal and life-threatening incidents have highlighted the importance of wearing a life jacket, but differing rules around the country can cause confusion.

title.children: Life jacket rules differ throughout the country. So what are they?

image.altText: Nine players in whites and red caps hug and celebrate on a green field.

props.synopsis: South Australia currently sits on top of both the first-class and one-day competitions as it returns from the international break.

title.children: SA is in prime position to break 29-year Sheffield Shield drought

image.altText: A sign promotes the hydrogen plant.

props.synopsis: The SA government's $600 million in hydrogen plant proposal has been plunged into doubt, with the premier indicating the money could be spent elsewhere in Whyalla if the owner of the city's steelworks does not invest in upgrading the site.

title.children: Hydrogen plant in doubt as SA premier refuses to commit to $600m project

image.altText: A street post with one way pointing to 'Historic Way' and the other way pointing to 'Offensive Place'

props.synopsis: Places and their names can hold different meanings for different people, but what happens when those in a community are uncomfortable with a historical figure or the association a place is named after?

title.children: Hundreds of places in Australia contain this 'racist slur' that experts want changed

image.altText: A man holding two bunches of grapes in a vineyard in front of a tractor.

props.synopsis: Drought, heat and frost have cut yields and pushed SA's wine industry into an early vintage, but a silver lining looms in the promise of high quality wines as a result.

title.children: SA vintage kicks off early but shows promise of excellent wine

image.altText: Two Australian wheelchair rugby players sit on court in their chairs, smiling and holding an Australian flag behind them.

props.synopsis: Australia's Steelers are coming home to host the inaugural Wheelchair Rugby World Challenge in Adelaide.

title.children: Australia to host new global wheelchair rugby tournament in Adelaide

image.altText: An early morning drone shot of a hill with underground homes built into it at White Cliffs, in outback NSW.

props.synopsis: Locals and first responders are being supported following the death of a boy on a remote property in Far West New South Wales.

title.children: Teen driver released from hospital after 9yo's death in ute rollover

image.altText: An aerial shot of pine forestry plantations.

props.synopsis: A plan to build more than 100 wind turbines in pine plantations close to a unique wetland in south-west Victoria is out for public comment.

title.children: $1.2b wind farm plan for plantations near Ramsar-listed wetland

image.altText: Back Roads crew with Uluru in the background. The man on the left has a video camera strapped to him, another has a microphone

props.synopsis: The Outback Way is the stuff of legends — thousands of kilometres of dirt road through the centre of Australia into uncharted territory and to places most people can only dream of seeing. But it's certainly not for the faint-hearted, writes Lisa Millar.

title.children: Dubbed Australia's longest shortcut, the Outback Way is not for the faint-hearted

image.altText: person hauls a car along an iced road in the snow

props.synopsis: Adelaide's Aaron Crook is the sole Australian among 11 global competitors who will race each other 620 kilometres in temperatures as low as -50 degrees Celsius across the Arctic Circle.

title.children: Athlete ready to risk Arctic frostbite in 'hardest, most epic' race yet

image.altText: Anthony Albanese at Garma Festival

props.synopsis: The federal government is promising $842.6 million over six years for remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, including for essential services such as policing, women's safety and alcohol harm reduction.

title.children: Federal government pledges $840m towards Closing the Gap in the NT

image.altText: Pauline Hanson speaking

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton held a rare press conference, as did Pauline Hanson, who left 28 long awkward seconds of silence after announcing her new policy.

title.children: Pauline Hanson called a press conference to announce a major policy. What followed was awkward silence

image.altText: A firefighter can be seen in the foreground fighting a house on fire. They are a silhouette against flames

props.synopsis: A US lawyer wants an electivity provider to take responsibility for their part in the Eaton fires in Los Angeles.

title.children: LA locals believe falling power lines sparked the recent fires, now they're suing

props.synopsis: Around-the-clock coverage of news events as they break, at home and abroad.

title.children: Watch: News Channel

image.altText: Minister Rose Jackson, with a political poster of NSW Premier Chris Minns behind her.

props.synopsis: While Rose Jackson has conceded the birthday lunch that helped trigger Jo Haylen's resignation was a mistake, the NSW mental health minister still has enough on her plate to worry about: the mass exit of the state's psychiatrists.

title.children: Why Jackson’s ill-advised long lunch could be the least of her worries

image.altText: Crowds of people walk from the Martin Place station in central sydney.

props.synopsis: Positive signs around falling inflation are balanced against increased uncertainty, which threatens to weigh on household consumption and business investment.

title.children: Signs point to inflation falling but jump in unemployment 'cannot be ruled out'

image.altText: A calendar graphic showing a potential election date and key dates.

props.synopsis: Trying to guess the election date before the prime minister reveals his thinking is always a somewhat futile exercise, but that has never got in the way of feverish speculation throughout the press gallery and beyond.

title.children: Why some Saturdays are more likely than others for the federal election

image.altText: Chappell Roan performs during the 67th Annual Grammy Awards.

props.synopsis: Have you been paying attention to the news this week? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Chappell's award plea, one big bear, and how Putricia actually smells

image.altText: A humpback whlae breaching the surface of the water.

props.synopsis: Scientists have discovered that human language and whale songs have remarkable similarities in the way they are segmented and structured.

title.children: Whale songs follow 'a lot of the same rules' as human language

image.altText: a plume of smoke arises from a bushfire

props.synopsis: As Tasmania battles more than a dozen fires sparked by a band of dry lightning strikes, some in high-value wilderness areas, researchers are raising the possibility that this is the 'new normal'.

title.children: Tasmania's wilderness areas at increasing risk of fire, researchers say

image.altText: A close up of Clive Palmer wearing a blue business shirt in focus with green trees blurred in the background.

props.synopsis: Clive Palmer will take his fight to the in the High Court in Canberra today, as he seeks to re-register his United Australia Party (UAP) ahead of the next federal election.

title.children: Palmer locked in High Court battle to re-register United Australia Party

image.altText: A smiling mother with her newborn girl.

props.synopsis: Amid the tragedy and destruction in flood-ravaged North Queensland there has also been joy.

title.children: Hospital a 'beacon of light' as mum gives birth in flood-ravaged town

image.altText: A lawyer dressed for a court and a woman in a suit arrive at the Federal Court.

props.synopsis: The ABC managing director told an unlawful termination hearing he reviewed Antoinette Lattouf's social media feeds and grew concerned about what he saw.

title.children: ABC boss asked if the Lebanese race exists in Lattouf case

image.altText: A CIA emblem on the floor of a building.

props.synopsis: The CIA is offering all of its employees incentives to resign — and some say its part of a move by US President Donald Trump to stack the government in his favour.

title.children: Five US spy agencies are offering buyouts to every employee. Here's what's going on

image.altText: A family poses for a photo in front of a temple in Indonesia

props.synopsis: Lily Lumintang was reading an ABC story about her family's plea to remain in Australia when her lawyer called to say Home Affairs had granted their family visas, allowing them to avoid deportation and remain in Australia.

title.children: Indonesian family's Australian residency approved after ABC inquiries

image.altText: A generic image showing a woman holding up a photo of a breast in a bra to her bare chest.

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian government has set aside millions of dollars for a brand new public diagnostic breast-imaging clinic, but staff say it hasn't provided enough money to run the actual service.

title.children: 'Comedy sketch from Monty Python': Breast screening funding may not cover staff
